Tutorial 1: Spatial Transcriptomics (ST) + Cox Survival Analysis

This tutorial demonstrates a complete workflow for integrating Spatial Transcriptomics (ST) data with bulk RNA-seq data to perform a “Cox” survival analysis.

The example uses Colorectal Cancer (CRC) data to identify spatial spots associated with patient prognosis.

Full Python Script

This file is available in your repository at ST-Cox-CRC.py. The full code is included here for reference.

  1# TiRank Analysis Pipeline Example
  2# This script demonstrates how to use the TiRank library to integrate spatial transcriptomics (ST)
  3# and bulk transcriptomics data to identify phenotype-associated spots and determine significant clusters.
  4
  5# Import necessary libraries and modules
  6import warnings
  7warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")
  8
  9import torch
 10import pickle
 11import os
 12
 13from TiRank.Model import setup_seed, initial_model_para
 14from TiRank.LoadData import *
 15from TiRank.SCSTpreprocess import *
 16from TiRank.Imageprocessing import GetPathoClass
 17from TiRank.GPextractor import GenePairExtractor
 18from TiRank.Dataloader import generate_val, PackData
 19from TiRank.TrainPre import tune_hyperparameters, Predict, Pcluster, IdenHub
 20from TiRank.Visualization import plot_score_distribution, DEG_analysis, DEG_volcano, Pathway_Enrichment
 21from TiRank.Visualization import plot_score_umap, plot_label_distribution_among_conditions,plot_STmap
 22
 23# Set random seed for reproducibility
 24setup_seed(619)
 25
 26# --------------------------------------------
 27# 1. Load Data
 28# --------------------------------------------
 29
 30## 1.1 Select a path to save the results
 31savePath = "./ST_Survival_CRC"  # Main directory for saving results
 32savePath_1 = os.path.join(savePath, "1_loaddata")
 33if not os.path.exists(savePath_1):
 34    os.makedirs(savePath_1, exist_ok=True)
 35
 36## 1.2 Load clinical data
 37dataPath = "./CRC_ST_Prog/"  # Directory containing your data
 38path_to_bulk_cli = os.path.join(dataPath, "GSE39582_clinical_os.csv")
 39bulkClinical = load_bulk_clinical(path_to_bulk_cli)
 40view_dataframe(bulkClinical)  # Optional: view the clinical data DataFrame
 41
 42## 1.3 Load bulk expression profile
 43path_to_bulk_exp = os.path.join(dataPath, "GSE39582_exp_os.csv")
 44bulkExp = load_bulk_exp(path_to_bulk_exp)
 45view_dataframe(bulkExp)  # Optional: view the bulk expression DataFrame
 46
 47## 1.4 Check consistency between bulk expression and clinical data
 48check_bulk(savePath, bulkExp, bulkClinical)
 49
 50## 1.5 Load spatial transcriptomics (ST) data
 51path_to_st_folder = os.path.join(dataPath, "SN048_A121573_Rep1")
 52scAnndata = load_st_data(path_to_st_folder, savePath)
 53st_exp_df = transfer_exp_profile(scAnndata)
 54view_dataframe(st_exp_df)  # Optional: view the ST expression DataFrame
 55
 56# --------------------------------------------
 57# 2. Preprocessing
 58# --------------------------------------------
 59
 60## 2.1 Select a path to save preprocessing results
 61savePath_2 = os.path.join(savePath, "2_preprocessing")
 62if not os.path.exists(savePath_2):
 63    os.makedirs(savePath_2, exist_ok=True)
 64
 65## 2.2 Load the saved AnnData object from step 1
 66with open(os.path.join(savePath_1, "anndata.pkl"), "rb") as f:
 67    scAnndata = pickle.load(f)
 68
 69## 2.3 Preprocess the ST data
 70# Define the inference mode (e.g., "ST" for spatial transcriptomics)
 71infer_mode = "ST"  # Optional parameter
 72
 73# Filtering the data based on counts and mitochondrial gene proportion
 74scAnndata = FilteringAnndata(
 75    scAnndata,
 76    max_count=35000,    # Maximum total counts per cell
 77    min_count=5000,     # Minimum total counts per cell
 78    MT_propor=10,       # Maximum percentage of mitochondrial genes
 79    min_cell=10,        # Minimum number of cells expressing the gene
 80    imgPath=savePath_2  # Path to save images/results
 81)
 82# Optional parameters: max_count, min_count, MT_propor, min_cell
 83
 84# Normalize the data
 85scAnndata = Normalization(scAnndata)
 86
 87# Log-transform the data
 88scAnndata = Logtransformation(scAnndata)
 89
 90# Perform clustering on the data
 91scAnndata = Clustering(scAnndata, infer_mode=infer_mode, savePath=savePath)
 92
 93# Compute similarity matrix (optional distance calculation)
 94compute_similarity(
 95    savePath=savePath,
 96    ann_data=scAnndata,
 97    calculate_distance=False  # Set to True if distance calculation is needed
 98)
 99
100# Path to the pre-trained image processing model (ensure this file is in the package)
101pretrain_path = "./ctranspath.pth"
102
103# Number of pathological clusters to identify
104n_patho_cluster = 7  # Optional variable (adjust based on your data)
105
106# Perform image processing to get pathological classifications
107scAnndata = GetPathoClass(
108    adata=scAnndata,
109    pretrain_path=pretrain_path,
110    n_clusters=n_patho_cluster,
111    image_save_path=os.path.join(savePath_2, "patho_label.png")
112    # Advanced parameters: n_components (PCA components), n_clusters
113)
114
115# Save the processed AnnData object
116with open(os.path.join(savePath_2, "scAnndata.pkl"), "wb") as f:
117    pickle.dump(scAnndata, f)
118
119## 2.4 Clinical data preparation and splitting bulk data
120# Define the analysis mode (e.g., "Cox" for survival analysis)
121mode = "Cox"
122
123# Split data into training and validation sets
124generate_val(
125    savePath=savePath,
126    validation_proportion=0.15,  # Optional parameter: proportion of data for validation
127    mode=mode
128)
129
130## 2.5 Gene pair transformation
131# Initialize the GenePairExtractor with parameters
132GPextractor = GenePairExtractor(
133    savePath=savePath,
134    analysis_mode=mode,
135    top_var_genes=2000,       # Optional: number of top variable genes to select
136    top_gene_pairs=1000,      # Optional: number of top gene pairs to select
137    p_value_threshold=0.05,   # Optional: p-value threshold for gene pair selection
138    max_cutoff=0.8,           # Optional: upper cutoff for correlation coefficient
139    min_cutoff=-0.8           # Optional: lower cutoff for correlation coefficient
140)
141
142# Load data for gene pair extraction
143GPextractor.load_data()
144
145# Run the gene pair extraction process
146GPextractor.run_extraction()
147
148# Save the extracted gene pairs
149GPextractor.save_data()
150
151# --------------------------------------------
152# 3. Analysis
153# --------------------------------------------
154
155## 3.1 TiRank Analysis
156# Define paths for saving analysis results
157savePath_3 = os.path.join(savePath, "3_Analysis")
158if not os.path.exists(savePath_3):
159    os.makedirs(savePath_3, exist_ok=True)
160
161### 3.1.1 Data Loading and Preparation
162# Ensure the 'mode' variable is consistent throughout the analysis
163mode = "Cox"          # Analysis mode (e.g., "Cox" for survival analysis)
164infer_mode = "ST"     # Inference mode (e.g., "ST" for spatial transcriptomics)
165device = "cuda" if torch.cuda.is_available() else "cpu"  # Use GPU if available
166
167# Pack the data into DataLoader objects for training and validation
168PackData(
169    savePath=savePath,
170    mode=mode,
171    infer_mode=infer_mode,
172    batch_size=1024   # Optional parameter: batch size for DataLoader
173)
174
175### 3.1.2 Model Training
176# Set the encoder type for the model (e.g., "MLP" for multi-layer perceptron)
177encoder_type = "MLP"  # Optional parameter (options: "MLP", "Transformer", etc.)
178
179# Initialize model parameters
180initial_model_para(
181    savePath=savePath,
182    nhead=2,           # Optional: number of heads in multi-head attention (if using Transformer)
183    nhid1=96,          # Optional: hidden layer size 1
184    nhid2=8,           # Optional: hidden layer size 2
185    n_output=32,       # Optional: output size
186    nlayers=3,         # Optional: number of layers
187    n_pred=1,          # Optional: number of predictions (e.g., 1 for regression)
188    dropout=0.5,       # Optional: dropout rate
189    mode=mode,
190    encoder_type=encoder_type,
191    infer_mode=infer_mode
192)
193
194# Tune hyperparameters using Optuna or other optimization libraries
195tune_hyperparameters(
196    savePath=savePath,
197    device=device,
198    n_trials=5    # Optional parameter: number of hyperparameter tuning trials
199)
200
201### 3.1.3 Model Inference
202# Predict phenotype-associated spots and perform rejection (uncertainty estimation)
203Predict(
204    savePath=savePath,
205    mode=mode,
206    do_reject=True,        # Optional: whether to perform rejection
207    tolerance=0.05,        # Optional: tolerance level for rejection
208    reject_mode="GMM"      # Optional: rejection mode (e.g., "GMM" for Gaussian Mixture Model)
209)
210
211### 3.1.4 Identify Hubs and Significant Clusters
212# Identify hub spots based on categorical columns
213IdenHub(
214    savePath=savePath,
215    cateCol1="patho_class",        # First categorical column (e.g., pathological class)
216    cateCol2="leiden_clusters",    # Second categorical column (e.g., clustering result)
217    min_spots=10                   # Optional: minimum number of spots to consider a hub
218)
219
220# Perform permutation tests to identify significant clusters
221Pcluster(savePath=savePath, clusterColName="patho_class", perm_n=1001)
222Pcluster(savePath=savePath, clusterColName="leiden_clusters", perm_n=1001)
223Pcluster(savePath=savePath, clusterColName="combine_cluster", perm_n=1001)
224
225### 3.1.5 Visualization
226# Plot the distribution of prediction scores
227plot_score_distribution(savePath)  # Displays the probability score distribution
228
229# Plot UMAP embedding colored by prediction scores
230plot_score_umap(savePath, infer_mode)
231
232# Plot the distribution of labels among different conditions
233plot_label_distribution_among_conditions(savePath, group="patho_class")
234plot_label_distribution_among_conditions(savePath, group="leiden_clusters")
235plot_label_distribution_among_conditions(savePath, group="combine_cluster")
236
237# Plot spatial maps of the spots with cluster labels
238plot_STmap(savePath=savePath, group="combine_cluster")
239
240## 3.2 Differential Expression and Pathway Enrichment Analysis
241# Set thresholds for differential expression analysis
242fc_threshold = 2          # Optional: fold-change threshold
243Pvalue_threshold = 0.05   # Optional: p-value threshold
244do_p_adjust = True        # Optional: whether to adjust p-values for multiple testing
245
246# Perform differential expression analysis
247DEG_analysis(
248    savePath=savePath,
249    fc_threshold=fc_threshold,
250    Pvalue_threshold=Pvalue_threshold,
251    do_p_adjust=do_p_adjust
252)
253
254# Plot volcano plots for differential expression results
255DEG_volcano(
256    savePath=savePath,
257    fc_threshold=fc_threshold,
258    Pvalue_threshold=Pvalue_threshold,
259    do_p_adjust=do_p_adjust
260)
261
262# Perform pathway enrichment analysis using specified databases
263# Available databases can be found at: https://maayanlab.cloud/Enrichr/#libraries
264Pathway_Enrichment(
265    savePath=savePath,
266    database=["GO_Biological_Process_2023"]  # Optional: replace with desired databases
267)
